ranked_differential_diagnosis: Bilateral facial nerve paralysis (House-Brackmann Grade VI/VI)
Bilateral longitudinal temporal bone fractures with involvement of horizontal segment of facial nerve canal
Conductive hearing loss (left ear) secondary to ossicular chain disruption
Slight hearing loss at 250 Hz (right ear, type undetermined - bone conduction not tested due to patient sensitivity from fractures)

ordered_list: Immittance audiometry (Tympanometry and Acoustic Reflex Thresholds)

interpretations: CT: Bilateral longitudinal temporal bone fractures traversing horizontal segment of facial nerve canal; small subarachnoid hemorrhage; pulmonary contusions.
EMG: Performed in hospital (results not detailed in case).

Pure-tone audiometry: Right ear - slight hearing loss at 250 Hz, normal hearing 500-8000 Hz; masked bone conduction not performed due to patient sensitivity. Left ear - slight conductive hearing loss at 250-500 Hz, normal at 1000 Hz, mild conductive hearing loss at 2000-8000 Hz with air-bone gaps at 500 Hz and 2000-4000 Hz.
SAT: Slight loss bilaterally, consistent with pure-tone average. Word recognition scores not measured due to patient's bilateral facial paralysis limiting speech ability.

Tympanometry: Normal tympanograms bilaterally (Type A); canal volume 1.1 mL bilaterally; static admittance 0.8 mL right, 0.7 mL left; peak pressure 0 daPa right, -80 daPa left. Normal middle ear pressure and mobility suggests partial ossicular dislocation without total separation.

Acoustic Reflex Thresholds: Present at 100 dB HL for 1000 and 2000 Hz ipsilateral stimulation in right ear only; absent for right and left contralateral stimulation and left ipsilateral stimulation. Pattern indicates probe effect consistent with facial nerve pathology; elevated right ipsilateral ARTs suggest slightly more residual facial nerve function on right than left.
ENoG Initial: Right side - minimal response at 8 ms, amplitude 58 µV (normal ≥500 µV); masseter response noted at 5.3 ms. Left side - absent response; masseter response at 5.5 ms.
ENoG: Right side - stable response. Left side - initial recovery observed with emergence of facial nerve response.
ENoG: Right side - stable response. Left side - response present but beginning to decline.
Patient reported morning headaches and decreased lip sensation when lying down, attributed to skull base shifting during sleep due to bilateral fractures.
ENoG: Right side - response remains intact but does not improve. Left side - response disappeared completely, indicating critical distress of left facial nerve requiring surgical intervention.

proposed_items: Prednisone 60 mg daily (initiated prior to audiology visit, for 6 days)
Serial ENoG monitoring every 3-5 days until 21 days post-insult (extended to 29 days due to initial apparent recovery)
Surgical decompression of the left facial nerve (to reduce swelling and/or relieve pressure by removing small portion of temporal bone)
counseling_actions: Explain ENoG findings showing critical distress of left facial nerve with declining then absent response
Recommend surgical intervention for left facial nerve decompression
Continue monitoring right facial nerve for spontaneous recovery (response stable but low amplitude)
Discuss persistent conductive hearing loss management options (patient declined medical management due to mild degree)
Advise sleep positioning considerations given bilateral skull fractures affecting nerve status

red_flags_present: Bilateral facial nerve paralysis (House-Brackmann Grade VI/VI) - complete paralysis
Declining then absent ENoG response on left side indicating Wallerian degeneration and critical nerve distress
Head trauma with bilateral longitudinal temporal bone fractures
Positional symptoms (headaches, decreased lip sensation when lying down) suggesting skull base instability affecting left facial nerve

escalation.rationale_short: Left facial nerve showed initial recovery on serial ENoG then declined to absent response by day 15, indicating critical distress and need for surgical decompression to preserve facial function.

follow_up_plan.timeline: 1 week post-operative, 2 months post-operative, 6 months post-operative
objectives: Monitor facial nerve function recovery using House-Brackmann grading
Assess hearing status and conductive hearing loss
Evaluate tympanometry and acoustic reflex recovery

expected_outcome: 1 week post-op: Upper brow and lip movement on left side of face observed.
2 months post-op: Significant facial recovery achieved (House-Brackmann Grade III/VI).
6 months post-op: Full facial recovery bilaterally (House-Brackmann Grade I/VI).

Persistent findings: Conductive hearing loss in left ear (consistent with ossicular chain disruption); left tinnitus, decreased hearing, and aural fullness reported but patient declined medical management; tympanometry remained normal; acoustic reflex thresholds did not recover.
key_clinical_points: ENoG is essential for determining treatment course and prognosis in facial nerve paralysis cases.
Greater than 90% denervation indicates need for surgical intervention; less than 90% has high spontaneous recovery rate.
In bilateral involvement, percent denervation calculation is not appropriate; instead monitor overall amplitude changes.
Wallerian degeneration occurs over 72 hours; baseline ENoG should be performed after this period.
Monitoring typically continues to 21 days post-onset but may extend if nerve shows initial recovery.
Temporal bone fracture patients are at risk for conductive, mixed, or sensorineural hearing loss requiring comprehensive audiological evaluation.
